newsitem.title: USA: China/FSU alumina imports to grow - Brook Hunt.
newsitem.headline: China/FSU alumina imports to grow - Brook Hunt.

text.p: China and the Former Soviet Union will remain big importers of alumina for their aluminum production, with half of the latter's refinery capacity heading for closure because of high cost and dwindling bauxite reserves, Julian Kettle of consultants Brook Hunt said.
Some two tonnes of alumina is needed to produce one tonne of aluminum metal.
Brook Hunt forecast an alumina price of $210 a tonne this year, up from about $200 at the start of the year.
Chinese alumina capacity is 3.36 million tonnes a year, but output from its six plants totaled 2.505 million tonnes in 1996, Kettle told Metal Bulletin's Bauxite and Alumina Seminar.

But to meet demand for aluminum in China, smelter output will have to expand 6 percent a year, but high domestic power costs will ensure that China remains a significant importer of alumina, importing some 1.2 to 1.4 million tonnes a year between now and 2001.
In the FSU alumina refineries produced 84 percent of the alumina needed by domestic smelters in 1992 but this fell to 70 percent last year, and is forecast to reach 50 percent by 2001.
"There will be a continuation of the downward spiral," Kettle said.
Kettle expected FSU aluminum production to remain at 3.0 to 3.5 million tonnes a year until 2001.
FSU alumina production capacity in 1996 was 5.812 million tonnes, with output at 4.379 million tonnes as the sector operated well below capacity.
The bulk of last year's alumina output was in Russia with 2.142 million tonnes, and a further 1.161 million tonnes in the Ukraine, and 1.076 million tonnes in Kazakhstan.
Kettle expected five FSU alumina refineries, Bauxitigorsk, Achinsk, Zaporozhye, Uralsk, and Bogoslovsk to close in the medium term becaue of high production costs and low ore reserves.
The five plants account for half of the FSU's alumina refinery capacity.
Alumina capacity in the FSU in 2001 will be 3.1 million tonnes a year, some 1.4 million tonnes less than last year.
FSU imports of alumina by 2001 could be some 3 million tonnes a year.
